description:
Vespertilio murinus, commonly known as the particolored bat or bicolored bat, is a species of vesper bat found in Europe and Asia. It is a medium-sized bat, with a wingspan of around 28-33 cm and a body length of 5-6 cm.

The distinctive feature of this species is its bicolored fur, with the dorsal (upper) side being dark brown to black, and the ventral (lower) side being light grey to white. This unique coloration is believed to provide camouflage and thermoregulation benefits.

Vespertilio murinus is a predominantly nocturnal species, emerging from its roosts at dusk to forage for insects, particularly moths and other flying insects. It is an agile flyer, using its echolocation abilities to navigate and locate prey.

The species is widely distributed, ranging from Western Europe to Central Asia, and is generally considered to be of least concern in terms of conservation status. However, it may face threats from habitat loss, disturbance of roosts, and the use of pesticides that can impact its insect prey.

Research on Vespertilio murinus has contributed to our understanding of bat biology, ecology, and behavior, providing insights into the adaptations and evolution of this unique mammalian group.
